title: Giving & Receiving Feedback
description: Learn how to give and receive feedback that helps you both grow.

questions.text: When you give me feedback, I prefer it to be...
choices: Timed well, not in the heat of things

therapeutic.rationale: Feedback preferences shape how information lands. Direct types want clarity; gentle types want care; specific types want actionability; timing-sensitive types need the right moment. Misaligned feedback delivery can cause hurt instead of growth.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different feedback preferences require adaptation. What feels caring to you may feel too soft or too harsh to your partner.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched feedback preferences create smooth, effective communication about growth areas.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you prefer to receive feedback? Have you told your partner?

questions.text: When I have feedback for you, I tend to...
choices: Share it directly because I care
Ask if you're open to hearing it first

therapeutic.rationale: Feedback-giving styles reflect care and communication patterns. Direct sharers prioritize truth; moment-waiters prioritize timing; softeners prioritize feelings; askers prioritize consent. Understanding your style helps you adjust to your partner's needs.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different giving styles may need adjustment. Your approach may not match what your partner needs.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched styles create natural feedback dynamics.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you tend to give feedback? Is that working for your partner?

questions.text: What makes me most open to hearing feedback is...
choices: When I trust the person giving it

therapeutic.rationale: Openness factors reveal what enables receptivity. Love-needer need safety; askers need control; balance-needers need affirmation; trust-needers need security. Knowing what opens your partner up helps feedback land well.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different openness factors require understanding your partner's needs, not assuming they're like yours.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched openness factors create natural conditions for productive feedback.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes you most open to hearing feedback? Does your partner know this?

questions.text: The most helpful feedback you've given me was about...
choices: How I communicate or express myself
How I handle stress or emotions
How I show up in our relationship

therapeutic.rationale: Remembering valuable feedback honors past growth. Communication feedback improved expression; stress feedback improved regulation; habit feedback improved behavior; relationship feedback improved partnership. Acknowledging helpful feedback encourages more.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different valued feedback shows you've grown in different areas. Both memories are valid.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched memories show you both valued similar growth conversations.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's the most helpful feedback your partner has given you? Did you thank them?

questions.text: I believe feedback in a relationship should...
choices: Be given lovingly and received openly
Help us grow without hurting each other

therapeutic.rationale: Feedback philosophies shape how couples communicate about growth. Love/openness believers emphasize safety; growth/no-hurt believers emphasize care; invitation believers emphasize consent; balance believers emphasize both truth and kindness. All are healthy approaches.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different feedback philosophies can blend. The core is that feedback should serve growth while preserving connection.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared philosophy creates aligned expectations for how you'll share feedback.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What role should feedback play in your relationship? Are you both comfortable with how it's given?
